Geography: China: Zhejiang province (Jiaxin, Pinghu, Haining, Jingning)
Maladies Treated: bone and joint tuberculosis (骨結核; 關節結核)
wind-rash, scabies, and tinea (風疹疥癬)
flatulence with intestinal rumbling (腹脹腸鳴)
fullness in the uterus due to accumulation of blood (子宮血痞)
Dosage: 3–9 g in decoction. 3 g taken as powder form.
Samples of Formulae:
Indication: Chronic eczema or urticaria.

Name of formula: wu shao she xiao feng yin.

Composition: wu shao she (Chinese rat snake) 3 g, ground to powder; chan tui (Cicada slough) 12 g; dang dui (Angelica sinensis root) 15 g; chi shao (Red peony root) 12 g; fang feng (Saposhnikovia root) 10 g; jing jie (Schizonepeta) 10 g; di fu zi (Kochia fruit) 18 g; chai hu (Bupleurum root) 6 g; bai ji li (Tribulus fruit) 10 g; gan cao (Licorice root) 3 g.

Preparation and administration: Cook with water (decoct), strain, and use as tea.
Contraindications: Do not use in cases of yinxu (yin deficiency) with internal heat. Contraindicated in stroke-like illness of deficiency pattern (類中風而屬虛者).
Research:
Anti-inflammatory effects: Water decoction of wu shao she at 10–20 g/kg or alcohol extract at 5–10 g/kg significantly inhibited xylene-induced ear edema in mice and agar-induced paw swelling in rats; the anti-inflammatory intensity was comparable to hydrocortisone 15 mg/kg [1].

Analgesic effects: In mouse hot-plate and writhing tests, the above doses of water decoction or alcohol extract showed significant analgesic effects equivalent to 40 mg/kg of Rotundine [1].

Other effects: Water decoction or alcohol extract possesses anticonvulsant effect [1]. Wu shao she serum possesses an anti-venom effect [2].
References: Zhong Hua Ben Cao 中華本草，蒙藥卷. http://www.med126.com/mingzu/2009/20090512113821_152409.shtml

Name: shi di
shi zi
persimmons
Other name: tai wan hei tan 台灣黑檀

Geography: Original place of distribution: along the Yangtze River of China (中國大陸長江流域一帶)
Properties: shi di (calyx/stem of fruit): bitter, astringent; neutral (性平)
Fruit (persimmon): sweet, astringent, cold; also listed as acrid
Samples of Formulae:
For cold-type hiccups: use Shi Di (persimmon calyx) with Ding Xiang (clove).

For hot-type hiccups: use Shi Di (persimmon calyx) with Zhu Ru (bamboo shavings).

Ding Xiang Shi Di Tang (Jisheng Fang): Indication: hiccups. Composition: Ding Xiang (clove) 2 g, Shi Di (persimmon calyx) 3 g, Ren Shen (ginseng) 3 g, Gan Jiang (dried ginger) 2 g. Preparation: decoct in water. Administration: take the decoction in two divided doses in one day.
Contraindications:
Persimmons contain tannin acid. If eaten with high-protein food like meat or fish, the protein can be hardened and form tannin albuminate, which is difficult to digest, and in some people can cause constipation.

Because persimmons are cold in characteristics, people with cold-type body (yang deficiency) should avoid eating them.

Overconsumption of persimmons can cause stercolith (fecal stones) in the intestines [2]. Stercolith can cause constipation or even cause gastrointestinal perforation [1].
Research: Note: there is little research on the polyphenols of persimmon in the West because it is not a popular food item among Westerners.
Notes: The white powder on the surface of many commercially sold dried persimmons is usually titanium oxide applied during processing. This added white powder is loose, easily falls off, and feels sticky on the hands; frosting is common. In contrast, naturally formed white powder during the drying process does not fall off easily, and the degree of frosting varies among individual fruits.
References: [1] J Coll Physicians Surg Pak. 2012 Jul;22(7):455-7. doi: 07.2012/JCPSP.455457.
[2] Source: Chen Xuanwei, director of Pediatrics of Taizhong city (Taiwan) Hospital (author is also a neonatology specialist).

ye ming sha (bat feces): corneal clouding
Cataract with blood stasis (血淤) treated with a modified tao ren si wu tang (Peach Kernel Four-Substance Decoction) formula
Samples of Formulae:
For cataract with blood stasis (血淤)
Name of Formula: tao ren si wu tang (Peach Kernel Four-Substance Decoction) — source: Yi Zong Jin Jian — with added ingredients.
Prescription (English version): tao ren (Peach kernel) 10 g, hong hua (Safflower) 10 g, chi shao (Red peony root) 10 g, bai shao (White peony root) 10 g, dan shen (Salvia root) 10 g, gou qi zi (Goji berry / Lycium fruit) 10 g, ju hua (Chrysanthemum flower) 10 g, bai ji li (Tribulus fruit) 10 g, chan yi (Cicada slough) 1.5 g, ye ming sha (bat feces) 4 g, qing xiang zi (Celosia seed) 6 g, cao jue ming (Cassia/Senna seed) 10 g, ci shi (Magnetite/Lodestone) 2 g, shen qu (Medicated leaven) 12 g, san shen (Mulberry fruit) 20 g, chen pi (Aged tangerine peel) 1 g, dang gui (Chinese angelica root) 12 g.
Prescription (Chinese version): 桃仁 (tao ren, Peach kernel) 10克，紅花 (hong hua, Safflower) 6克，丹參 (dan shen, Salvia root) 10克，赤芍 (chi shao, Red peony root) 10克，白芍 (bai shao, White peony root) 10克，枸杞子 (gou qi zi, Goji berry) 10克，菊花 (ju hua, Chrysanthemum flower) 10克，白蒺藜 (bai ji li, Tribulus fruit) 10克，蟬蛻 (chan tui/chan yi, Cicada slough) 1.5克，夜明砂 (ye ming sha, bat feces) 4克，青葙子 (qing xiang zi, Celosia seed) 6克，草決明 (cao jue ming, Cassia/Senna seed) 10克，磁石 (ci shi, Magnetite/Lodestone) 2克，神麴 (shen qu, Medicated leaven) 12克，桑椹 (san shen, Mulberry fruit) 20克，陳皮 (chen pi, Aged tangerine peel) 1克，當歸 (dang gui, Chinese angelica root) 12克。
Preparation and administration: Add water to make a decoction. One prescription per day, divided into 3 servings.
Note: The weight of the herbs must be adjusted according to diagnosis 
 Clinical report on cataract with blood stasis treated using a modified tao ren si wu tang: Total patients: 200 persons with 381 diseased eyes. Initial onset (新近/初發): 127 cases. Not yet ripened (未成熟): 73 cases. Cortical type (皮質性): 240 eyes. Nuclear type (核性): 141 eyes. Total effectiveness: 98.4%.

Geography: China: found in most provinces except Northeastern area, Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (青藏高原), Shanxi, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, and Xinjiang.
China — distributed in: Hebei, Henan, Jiangsu, Shandong, Anhui, Guangdong, Guangxi, Hubei, Sichuan, Yunnan, Shaanxi.
China — main production areas: Hubei, Anhui, Hunan, Jiangsu, Zhejiang; also produced in Guangdong, Sichuan, Guizhou, Fujian, Shaanxi, Henan, and Shanghai.
Maladies Treated: gu zheng lao re (骨蒸勞熱; steaming bone disorder with tidal fever).
hot flashes with night sweating (潮熱盜汗).
yin xu yang kang (陰虛陽亢).
yin xu dong feng (陰虛動風).
chronic ache in the loin and knees (腰膝酸痛).
weakness in knees and feet of the aged (老人腳膝痿弱).
spermatorrhea and chronic cough (遺精久咳).
soft bones in small children (小兒軟骨).
late development of teeth in small children and late fusing of the anterior fontanel (小兒齒遲行遲及前囟門不合).
over abundance of bleeding during menses (月經過多).
heat in blood with bleeding not during menses (血熱崩漏).
dark purple pieces of blood during menses (經行紫黑成塊).
Medical Function: Improves anti-cancer ability (能提高機體抗癌的能力).
Dosage:
Internal use (decoction): 10–24 g. Suitable to roast in sand. If using raw shells, boil before other herbs.

External use: char to retain properties, grind into powder, and apply to the affected area.
Samples of Formulae:
1) For forgetfulness in studying — Name: Pills in the Pillow of Confucius (孔聖枕中丹). Composition: stale gui ban (Tortoise plastron) — bake till crispy; long gu (Dragon bone) — make into powder and put into the cavity of a killed chicken and cook for a day; yuan zhi (Polygala root); chang pu (Acorus rhizome). Use equal amounts of each ingredient and make into pills. Indication: forgetfulness in studying; long-term use makes one intelligent.

2) Da Bu Yin Wan (Dan Xi Xin Fa). Application: yinxu (yin deficient) with fever; for yinxu with fire, gu zheng lao re, cough with blood, night sweating, and spermatorrhea. Composition: gui ban (Tortoise plastron; bake till brittle) 180 g; shu di huang (Prepared Rehmannia root; steam with rice wine) 180 g; zhi mu (Anemarrhena rhizome; stir-fry with rice wine) 120 g; huang bai (Phellodendron bark; stir-fry till brown) 120 g. Grind into fine powder. Mix with steamed pork spinal marrow and refined honey; form pills about 15 g each. Dosage: one pill in the morning and one in the evening with light salt water. May also be prepared as a decoction using the same proportions with reduced herb amounts.

3) Hu Qian Wan (虎潛丸).
Contraindications:
Do not use in cases of yangxu (yang deficient) or pixu (spleen deficient). Do not use when external pathogens (cold/flu) have not yet been resolved. Use with care during pregnancy; pregnant women should not use. Do not use in patients who are weak and without fever [2].

The herb is cold in nature and can reduce yang qi. It should not be used in cases of yang deficient with false heat, piyangxu (spleen yang deficiency; spleen–stomach cold), mingmen yang deficiency cold, and similar patterns. If misused for a long time, it will damage the spleen and impair appetite [1].
Notes:
gui ban jiao (Colla Plastrum Testudinis) is more concentrated and stronger than gui ban (Plastrum testudinis). It is the gelatin obtained by prolonged cooking of tortoise shell.

In the naming of forms, jiao means glue.

Shell (general: tortoise shell/plastron): amino acids: aspartate, threonine, methionine, phenylalanine, leucine
inorganic ions: K+, Na+, Ca2+, Fe3+, P
Back and abdomen shell — after acid hydr: yielded 16 same kinds of amino acids

Name: lu e mei
綠萼梅
Common: Japanese apricot flower with green calyx

Geography: Originated in China; produced in Sichuan, Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, Hunan, Guizhou, and Jiangxi; those produced in Changxin (長興) of Zhejiang are deemed best.
Maladies Treated: Stomachache due to dominant liver qi (肝氣盛所引起的腹痛)
Globus hystericus (梅核氣; sensation of obstruction in the throat during hysteria attacks)
Scrofula (淋巴結核; tuberculosis of lymph nodes)
Contraindications: Long-term usage is not suitable for those who are yinxu (yin deficient) with serious sickness, accompanied by red tongue without fur, scant fluids, dry mouth, and preference for cold drinks.
Notes:
The variety with green calyx is called lu e mei, literally “apricot (flowers) with green calyx.” In Ben Cao Gang Mu (本草綱目) it is called bai hua mei, literally “white flower plum.”
Original: Prunus mume (Sieb.) Sieb. et Zucc. (pages 61, 268). Correction: Armeniaca mume Sieb. Commentary: This species belongs to the genus Armeniaca (apricot), whereas the genus name adopted by the Pharmacopoeia (Prunus) is now the genus name for plum; the scientific name recorded by the Pharmacopoeia is a synonym. (Comment by Shen Bao-an, Wuhu City, Anhui Province Drug Inspection Institute 241001).

Flower: Volatile (evaporating) oil: chiefly benzaldehyde (phenylaldehyde; benzenecarbonal; C7H6O)
Benzoic acid (also known as acidum benzoicum)
